final_answer.precision_note: 3 significant figures matching the least precise input (0.150 mol dm-3 with 3 sig figs)

method: First calculate moles of NaOH used: n(NaOH) = c × V = 0.150 mol dm-3 × (23.40/1000) dm3 = 0.00351 mol. From the balanced equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O, the mole ratio of H2SO4 to NaOH is 1:2, so moles of H2SO4 = 0.00351 / 2 = 0.001755 mol. The concentration of H2SO4 is calculated using c = n/V: c(H2SO4) = 0.001755 mol / (25.00/1000) dm3 = 0.001755 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3. The answer is given to 3 significant figures consistent with the input data precision.
checks: H2SO4 is diprotic acid requiring 2 moles NaOH per mole acid - stoichiometry correctly applied
Calculated concentration is lower than NaOH concentration, expected for acid neutralized by base of similar concentration
Volume conversion cm3 to dm3 correctly applied by dividing by 1000
